results.title: South India
results.creator_credit: Jez Higham, Emma Cahwac and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Justine Shapiro explores India’s southern tip, travelling through the state of Tamil Nadu, and then on to tropical Kerala where she tours its famed network of backwaters and canals. Justine ends her journey on the rarely visited Lakshadweep islands in the middle of the Arabian Sea. Other activities covered in the journey include: eating at a vegetarian restaurant where 3,000 customers lunch everyday, riding on a bullock cart to a Hindu temple at Tiravanamali, travelling to an elephant sanctuary and bathing them, and visiting one of India’s few female gurus who has hugged over ten million people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jez Higham, Emma Cahwac and Pilot Films

results.title: New York
results.creator_credit: Paul McGuiaan, Benita Matofska and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
New York is a vast metropolis and its famous skyline makes it one of the world’s most spectacular cities. New York is also home to a multitude of ethnic groups who have created a mosaic of diverse cultures and enclaves. Ian Wright visits the famous landmarks found in every promotional brochure but also finds some interesting surprises rarely visited by tourists off the beaten track. Activities covered include: budget hotels, yellow taxis and New York clubland, kosher food on the Lower East Side, visits to the Empire State Building, Central Park and the Statue of Liberty, Harlem, the Bronx and Brooklyn, and a helicopter flight over the city.

results.title: The Castle of Adventure
results.creator_credit: Terry Marcel, Edward Francis and TVS Films
results.brief_description: Enid Blyton’s famous adventure story about five children, a sinister castle and a network of spies is brought vividly to life. A young widowed mother, takes her two children and friends to stay at a country cottage during the school holidays. They befriend a young gypsy girl who lives in the nearby woods. Across the valley, stand the dark, brooding remains of a mysterious ruined castle. The five children launch an expedition to discover the castle’s secrets.

results.title: The Castle
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Debra Choate and Working Dog
results.brief_description: How Darryl Kerrigan, average working joe, and his small time suburban lawyer mate, Denis Denuto ended up in the High Court of Australia is the story told in ‘The Castle’. The Kerrigan family live at 3 Highview Crescent, Cooloroo, on the edge of an international airport, in total obscurity. That is until the consortium owning the airport decide to expand and the land surrounding the airport is to be compulsorily acquired from the residents. What the powers-that-be did not count on was the dogged determination of Darryl Kerrigan, greyhound racer, tow-truck driver with a keen eye for a bargain, to whom his house is his family’ home and a very happy one at that. Ordinary family.

results.title: North India
results.creator_credit: Stephen Lennhoff, Phil Frank and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Experience Northern India with another ‘Lonely Planet’ travelling video. Climb an elephant’s trunk, learn yoga at an ashram, float along the sacred River Ganges, take a rickshaw to the Taj Mahal and spin prayer wheels in a Buddhist gompa.

results.title: Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands
results.creator_credit: Peter Boyd MacLean, Caroline Stuart and Pilot Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Justine Shapiro travels off the beaten track on a tour of Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands. She visits hot springs heated by a volcano, views the countryside from the roof of a train and almost tries roast guinea pig. A highlight of the journey is a visit to the Amazon forest, guided by the indigenous people of the area. The Galapagos Islands were made famous by Charles Darwin in developing his theory of evolution and are home to a fascinating diversity of wildlife, with many species found nowhere else in the world.

results.title: The Castaway cowboy
results.creator_credit: Vincent McEveety, Ron Miller, Winston Hibler and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Disney family film about a shipwrecked cowboy, Lincoln Costain (James Garner) on a Hawaiian island, and his adventures with widow Henrietta MacAvoy (Vera Miles) and land baron Bryson (Robert Culp). Henrietta has a struggling potato farm and through the aid of Lincoln, the farm is eventually turned into a successful cattle ranch. Bryson, who holds Henrietta’s mortgage, wants her land and is prepared to go to any length to get it. On confronting this predicament Lincoln has to decide whether to stay and fight for Henrietta or return to his home in Texas. Cast includes Eric Shea, Elizabeth Smith, Manu Tupou.

results.title: Vietnam
results.creator_credit: Stephen Lennhoff, Phil Frank and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Hosted by Justine Shapiro, this Lonely Planet video explores the subterranean tunnels once inhabited by the Vietcong, takes part in new years celebrations with fireworks heralding the arrival of a new year, takes alternative medicine- drinking snake juice to ward off sickness, and riding the Reunification express.

results.title: The Cars that ate Paris. The Plumber [DVD]
results.brief_description: The Plumber: There is an unexpected knock on the door and Jilly (Judy Morris) an anthropologist, opens it to a strange man who says he is the plumber (Ivor Kants). Weir deftly crafts a tense thriller, as the man is not all he seems and Jilly is tormented by the man’s presence and mind games over the next five days as he totally disrupts her life. Her husband, a university doctor (Robert Coleby), seems oblivious to her anguish and just wants the shower fixed. Disturbing and unsettling in mood, set in a high-rise apartment block with large balconies that feel lifeless and unconducive to a happy life, Jilly plots to play the plumber at his own game and foils his plans. Written and directed by Peter Weir. Production company: SAFC/Channel 9/AFC, copyright by Salt Pan Films 1978/2004, produced by Matt Carroll. Also available on VHS [301733]. The Cars that ate Paris: Peter Weir’s directorial feature film debut is an offbeat horror story/fantasy about a small Australian country town called Paris. Giving the term ‘road kill’ a whole new meaning, the townsfolk of Paris make a living out of the victims of road accidents by allowing a crazy psychiatrist to conduct experiments on them. They also prosper from the cars that cause the accidents but death, destruction and mayhem ensue as the cars turn against the town. John Meillon is wonderful as the chipper Town Mayor and Terry Camilleri portrays the disbelief in his character’s predicament very well. Production Company was AFDC and Royce Smeal Film Productions with copyright by Salt Pan Films 1974/2001. Produced by Hal and Jim McElroy and written and directed by Peter Weir. Cast includes: Chris Haywood, Bruce Spence, Kevin Miles, Max Gillies, Melissa Jaffer, Max Phipps. Released on DVD by ScreenSound Australia. Also available on VHS [016312].

They also prosper from the cars that cause the accidents but death, destruction and mayhem ensue as the cars turn against the town. John Meillon is wonderful as the chipper Town Mayor and Terry Camilleri portrays the disbelief in his character’s predicament very well. Production Company was AFDC and Royce Smeal Film Productions with copyright by Salt Pan Films 1974/2001. Produced by Hal and Jim McElroy and written and directed by Peter Weir. Cast includes: Chris Haywood, Bruce Spence, Kevin Miles, Max Gillies, Melissa Jaffer, Max Phipps. Released on DVD by ScreenSound Australia. Also available on VHS [016312].
description_for_label: The Plumber: There is an unexpected knock on the door and Jilly (Judy Morris) an anthropologist, opens it to a strange man who says he is the plumber (Ivor Kants). Weir deftly crafts a tense thriller, as the man is not all he seems and Jilly is tormented by the man’s presence and mind games over the next five days as he totally disrupts her life. Her husband, a university doctor (Robert Coleby), seems oblivious to her anguish and just wants the shower fixed. Disturbing and unsettling in mood, set in a high-rise apartment block with large balconies that feel lifeless and unconducive to a happy life, Jilly plots to play the plumber at his own game and foils his plans. Written and directed by Peter Weir. Production company: SAFC/Channel 9/AFC, copyright by Salt Pan Films 1978/2004, produced by Matt Carroll. Also available on VHS [301733]. The Cars that ate Paris: Peter Weir’s directorial feature film debut is an offbeat horror story/fantasy about a small Australian country town called Paris. Giving the term ‘road kill’ a whole new meaning, the townsfolk of Paris make a living out of the victims of road accidents by allowing a crazy psychiatrist to conduct experiments on them. They also prosper from the cars that cause the accidents but death, destruction and mayhem ensue as the cars turn against the town. John Meillon is wonderful as the chipper Town Mayor and Terry Camilleri portrays the disbelief in his character’s predicament very well. Production Company was AFDC and Royce Smeal Film Productions with copyright by Salt Pan Films 1974/2001. Produced by Hal and Jim McElroy and written and directed by Peter Weir. Cast includes: Chris Haywood, Bruce Spence, Kevin Miles, Max Gillies, Melissa Jaffer, Max Phipps. Released on DVD by ScreenSound Australia. Also available on VHS [016312].
